Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.

parts: Did Trump just propose banning sex change operations on children?

content.text: search("Did Trump just propose banning sex change operations on children?")

parts:
Yes, President Donald Trump has proposed banning sex change operations on children. In his address to Congress on March 4, 2025, he called for legislation to permanently ban and criminalize such procedures for minors, stating: "I want Congress to pass a bill permanently banning and criminalizing sex changes on children and forever ending the lie that any child is trapped in the wrong body." citeturn0news14

This proposal aligns with his previous actions, including the signing of Executive Order 14187 on January 28, 2025, titled "Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation." This order aims to prevent gender-affirming care for individuals under 19 by withholding federal funding and directing agencies to take steps to prevent surgeries, hormone therapy, puberty blockers, and other gender-affirming treatments. citeturn0search20

The executive order has faced legal challenges. On February 13, 2025, a federal judge issued a temporary restraining order blocking the enforcement of the order, preventing the withholding of federal funds from hospitals that provide gender-affirming care to minors. citeturn0news18

In summary, President Trump has both proposed and taken executive action to ban sex change operations on children, with ongoing legal challenges to these measures.

items.title: The Latest: Trump's joint address to Congress showed the country's stark partisan divide
items.snippet:
President Donald Trump's joint address to Congress was marked by his call for "swift and unrelenting action" to reshape the nation's economy, immigration, and foreign policy, highlighting sharp partisan divisions. Democrats visibly registered their dissent through stony reactions, signs calling out lies, and some even exiting the chamber. Representative Al Green was ejected after directly confronting Trump, reflecting the heightened tensions.

In contrast, Republicans enthusiastically supported Trump's messaging, which focused on themes like cutting diversity initiatives, advocating for firm immigration policies, and reinforcing conservative cultural values. Trump also emphasized his economic plans, including tariffs and a new "gold card" path to citizenship for wealthy immigrants, despite criticism from both political and economic analysts.

The Democratic response criticized Trump for not addressing rising prices and cutting essential programs, with Representatives Adriano Espaillat and Elissa Slotkin underscoring the political and social turmoil. Trump's lengthy address, which set a new record for longest speech to a joint session, underscored significant partisan divides, with Democrats departing while Republicans cheered his agenda.

items.title: Judge blocks Trump order threatening funding for institutions that offer care for transgender youth
items.snippet: A federal judge in Seattle has extended a temporary restraining order, blocking President Donald Trump's plan to withdraw federal funding from institutions providing gender-affirming care to transgender youth. This preliminary injunction was granted after the Democratic attorneys general from Washington, Oregon, and Minnesota, along with Colorado, sued the Trump administration. Trump's plan targeted institutions offering puberty blockers and hormone treatments, in addition to an unfounded threat of prosecuting medical professionals for providing this care. The lawsuit argues that such orders violate equal rights protections and states' rights. The judge emphasized the potential life-threatening consequences for transgender youth who might be denied essential care. The rulings challenge executive orders promoting gender ideology extremism and protecting children from medical procedures deemed unnecessary, questioning their validity and alignment with constitutional rights.
